children.text:
Pick a time when your baby is active. Press Start timer, then the Kick! button every time you feel your baby kick, turn, or move. The tool tracks how long it takes to record 10 movements and saves each session so you can see how they compare.

Try to count kicks around the same time every day. If you notice a major change, call your health provider. If you don't reach 10 movements in two hours, try to perk up your baby by eating a snack, drinking something cold, or walking around. Wait an hour and count kicks again. If you still don't reach 10 in two hours, call your provider.

Why count kicks?
Getting to know your baby's movement pattern can help you catch a problem early and may reduce the risk of stillbirth. Some practitioners advise starting daily kick counts at 28 weeks (or sooner if you have a high-risk pregnancy). There are lots of different methods for doing a kick count, so find out what your practitioner recommends.
